title: Diploma in Risk Management
headline: This free online course will give you a full and comprehensive run through of risk management procedures and practices.
description: This free online risk management course will help you identify perils and hazards and improve your skills in managing risk. Risk management is essential for the success of every business as it helps identify, assess, and manage financial problems at every turn. The course will teach you why there is a need for risk management tools as well as the main steps of risk management that every business professional needs to know.
courseDescription:
This course will first introduce you to risk management. You will learn the importance of risk management methodology and risk management tools following the 2008 financial collapse. You will study the ideal requisites for insurability, the types of insurance and insurers, and the essential elements of insurance contracts. The course will cover the criteria required for participants in a contract, the principle of indemnity, and the concepts of insurable interest and subrogation.

You will then study the classification of real and personal property and its effect on risk exposure and valuation. The course will discuss the five categories of e-commerce property risk, liability and legal ramifications, and the factors and solutions pertaining to global risk exposure. You will learn the most common source of liability with regard to activities/conduct and the benefits that are applicable to survivors of deceased insured workers. You will also study the six main life insurance riders and the benefits of group life insurance.

Risk is part of our daily lives and businesses. Whether you are driving a car or starting a business, the risk of damage and injury is there. Learning how to manage risk and having the right insurance measures in place will make it easier for you when things go wrong. This Diploma in Risk Management course will help you identify and explore potential risks in organizations so make sure to check it out and start learning how to control, prevent, and reduce losses that can result from risk.

Start Course Now

      Most risk professionals define risk in terms of an expected deviation of an occurrence, from what they expect - also known as anticipated variability. 

      In common English language, many people continue to use the word “risk”, as a noun to describe an enterprise, property, person, or activity, that is exposed to losses. 

      In contrast, most insurance industry contracts and education and training 
      materials, use the term "exposure", to describe the enterprise, property, person, or activity facing a potential loss. Thus, a house built on the coast near Galveston, Texas, is called an “exposure unit” because of the potential for loss, due to hurricanes.

  • Module One Summary

    • The global financial crisis of 2008, created unprecedented coordination of regulatory actions across countries and governmental involvement in managing risk at the enterprise level. 
    • Systemic risk differs from individuals being involved in risky enterprises, as it effects organizations. 
    • Uncertainty is a precursor to risk. 
    • Risk is a consequence of uncertainty.
    • Risk can be emotional, financial, or reputational.
    • The roles of Maximization of Value and Minimization of Losses, form a continuum on which risk is anchored.
    • One consequence of uncertainty, is that actual outcomes may vary from what is expected. As such this represents risk.
    • There are three main personified attitudes to risk: risk averse, risk neutral and risk seeker.
    • Pure risk features some chance of loss and no chance of gain (e.g. fire, flood, etc.)
    • Speculative risk features a chance to either gain or lose (investments, reputation, strategy etc.)
    • Diversifiable risks are those that can have their adverse consequences mitigated, by having a well-diversified portfolio of risk exposure.

  • Risk Matrix

  • In this topic you will learn about alternatives available for managing risks, based on their frequency and severity.
    Transferring risk, avoiding it and managing it internally with loss controls, is examined.

    Once risks are evaluated and forecasted, loss frequency and severity is used (vertical and horizontal lines) in a risk management matrix, to designate risk exposure. 

    A matrix differs from a risk map (which includes all important risks a firm is exposed to). The risk management matrix includes, on one axis, categories of relative frequency (high and low) and on the other, categories of relative severity (high and low). The simplest of these matrices, is one with four cells, as shown in the table on the next slide.

  • Module Two Summary

    • Communication is key in the risk management process. Various media are used, such as policy statements and manuals. 
    • The risk identification process includes profiling and risk mapping.
    • One of the most important tools in risk management is a risk map, where the frequency and severity of losses is projected, for each risk.
    • Within a framework of similar companies, the risk manager can tell when it is most appropriate to use risk transfer, reduction or retention.
    • Risk managers compare risk maps created for the identification of risks, with those representing the current handling of risks.
    • The risk management matrix tool is used for evaluating risks according to their frequency and severity and with respect to insurance, retention and avoidance.

    • Group insurance, is insurance provided by an employer for the benefit of employees. Group insurance coverage includes: life, disability, health and pension plans. 

      Personal insurance is insurance purchased by individuals and families for various risk needs, such as: life, health, disability, auto, homeowner and long-term care. 

      Commercial insurance is property/casualty insurance for businesses and other organizations.

      NOTE: An insurance company is likely to have separate divisions within its underwriting department for: personal lines, group lines and commercial business. The criterion to assign insureds into their appropriate risk pool, for rating purposes, is different for each type of insurance.

      Reasons for setting up a captive: 

      1) Captives give a company access to the reinsurance market for stop-loss catastrophic coverage for the captive.
      2) Captives allow a company to coordinate the insurance programs of their foreign operations.
      3) Captives allow companies to manage exchange rate risks as well as the pure risks more common to traditional risk managers. 
      4) Captives give a company access to the reinsurance market.

    • ACTUARIES
      Actuarial analysis is a highly specialized mathematical analysis, that deals with the financial and risk aspects of insurance.

      Actuarial analysis takes past losses and projects them into the future, to determine the reserves an insurer needs to keep and the rates to charge. 

      An actuary performs the following functions: 

      • Determines proper rates and reserves
      • Certifies financial statements
      • Participates in product development
      • Assists in overall management planning

  • Module Four Summary

    • The marketing function of insurance companies differs for life/health and property/casualty segments.
    • Agents represent insurers. They work under a general agency or as direct writers.
    • Brokers represent the insured and place policies with appropriate insurers.
    • Internet marketing, mass merchandising campaigns and financial planning are methods of acquiring customers.
    • Underwriting classifies the insured into the appropriate risk categories.
    • Actuarial analysis is used to project past losses into the future, to predict reserve needs and appropriate rates to charge.
    • Actuaries utilize loss development and mortality tables, to aid in setting premium rates and establishing adequate reserves.
    • Several adjustments are reflected in insurance premiums: anticipated investment earnings; marketing/administrative costs; taxes; risk premiums and profits.
    • Insurers use catastrophe modeling to predict future losses. 
    • A major component of insurance industry profits is investment income from the payment of premiums.

  • Module Five Summary

    • Contracts feature an offer, acceptance and consideration.
    • An insured must offer to buy and consider the premiums/policy conditions, and the agent must accept the offer (provide coverage), in order for an insurance contract to be enacted.
    • Parties to a contract must be competent. Mentally ill and intoxicated persons are not competent to contract.
    • A contract must be for legal purposes only. 
    • Contracts may be oral or written, but they must follow a legal form.
    • The concept of "utmost good faith", in insurance contracts, is the principle that the insurer provides coverage, based on the information that is given by the insured. If that information becomes known to be false, the contract can be considered null and void.
    • Insurance contracts are contracts of "adhesion", because the insured must accept the terms as stipulated.
    • In disputes between insurers and the insured, courts generally take the side of the insured, with respect to their interpretation of a contract (the contract "as understood by the insured").
    • Insurance contracts are contracts of indemnity (the insurer will pay no more or no less than the actual loss incurred).
    • Indemnity is supported by the concepts of: Insurable interest; Subrogation and Actual cash value.
    • 'Insurable interest' refers to the value of the cover, as defined in the contract.
